subject: Re: [junit] Another question on assertEquals()
msgSnippet: ... To compare objects that wrap floats, have the object s equals() method handle the tolerance, if non-zero differences are tolerable. To compare collections
messageBody:
Anna Skawinska wrote:
> Hi,
>
>
> comparing two floats is only possible, if you provide the method
> with accuracy passed as the third argument:
> assertEquals(double expected, double actual, double delta)
>
> The question is, how do I compare two objects which contain floats,
> tables of floats or composed objects, which in turn contain floats? Do
> I have to recurse through the inner fields, comparing them with the
> overloaded method appropriate for floats?
>
> Or am I wrong thinking the assertion doesn't work because of the
> float composition and it's probably the fault of my objects, which are
> not de facto equal?

To compare objects that wrap floats, have the object's equals() method
handle the tolerance, if non-zero differences are tolerable.

To compare collections that contain floats (pre-JDK 5.0), you have to
convert to Float or Double objects, for which equals() is implemented
not to allow non-zero differences, so you might be stuck there. I
imagine the same would happen with autoboxing in JDK 5.0+.

It's silly, but do you /have/ to use floating-point numbers? I have to
admit, I haven't used one in years, because floating-point arithmetic
irks me.
